title: Event Registry

author: Gregor Leban, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: So my name is Gregory Levin and I'm going to present a system called Event Registry.
So.
In one sentence, we can say that event registries assistant is like a wiki.
Wikipedia, like an encyclopedia for world events.
More specifically, we can say that Event Registry collects news articles that are published globally all over the world in different languages.
All the content which we collect is automatically analyzed, semantically enriched, and from this content.
We then extract information about the events which actually happen in the world, and we should described in these articles.
And all these events are then Additionally enriched by extracting also information where the event happened.
What happened, who is involved in the event, and so on.
And all these data is stored in a in a database where we can then provide extensive search options and visualizations.
So this will be.
Partly description of the technologies.

There are a lot of machine learning and AI methods in the background, so I'll be describing a few of those, but it can be also a technology which can easily be applied on other domains like open educational resources and so on.
So don't be too focused on the data itself, but it's more on the methods and what you can do with these kind of methods.
So why is event register useful?
So as you know we daily there are like hundreds of thousands of news articles that get published, so these articles are in different languages and they are provided in unstructured form.
Unstructured form means that it's provided in a plain text which is easy for humans to understand.

But it's very complex for the machines, so computers don't understand the text as we as we do and that's why we have to actually apply a lot of AI and machine learning to actually extract the meaning of the.
Text which is provided in this news.

And once we have this meaning, once we have the data extracted in a structured form, this structured form can then be stored and then used so that people can use various facets like finding content, finding specific events based on time, locations.
What's the topic of the event, and so on to find the specific subset of content which is relevant for the user or whoever uses the system.
And this guy kind of information or this kind of extraction of structured information is very useful for for people who work, let's say in risk analysis.
Who were policymakers stock traders, NGOs for financial institutions and many more?

Before we go into details how Event Registry actually works, we first have to just say a few words on what an event actually is, because that's like a very broad definition, and people usually have very different thoughts.
When you mention an event.

So for us, an event is something that is anything significant that happens in the world, and one assumption that we in this case make is that if there is something significant happening in the world, there will be news media reporting about this.
So this is a very strong assumption, but that's the kind of information that.
That we ingest.
So that's the way that's the kind of event definition that we can make.
So for us an event is there for our collection of news articles that we have identified, identified which we see that they describe the same event.
This talk about the same thing in here is 1 simple example.

So here is an example of an event that happened last year, so there was a fly by plane that crashed and you can also already see that kind of a template that we can extract from the original news articles.
So we extract the title of the event in a summary.
But we also extract when it happened.
What was the location of the event?
What is the event about?
Who are the main entities and nonentities involved in the event?
And so on.
And if.
You look at a few more examples, so here are more recent examples, so this is an event that happened last week, so there was an explosion on the underground in London.
So again we have the same template where it happened, when who was involved in?
What's the event about another one where we have refugees from Burundi who were killed in Congo?
So this is again demonstration where we have a number of articles in different languages discussing the same event.

And here is maybe another example which is not a typical what you would expect is a typical definition of an event, because here is an event where we found that UN report states that there is an increase in world hunger again.
So this is not an event in typical sense because it doesn't have a physical location.
So there was just simply a UN report which came out and there were a lot of media reports about this.
Which is why we can identify it as an event.
So.
How do we?
How do we find this kind of events?

So there's a long pipeline of steps that we have to do a lot of machine learning involved, and I don't have time and also this is not the right audience to discuss the details, technical details about how we do this, so I'll just mention a few.
Up difficult parts which explain why the whole task needs machine learning and why it's so complicated.
So one of the first steps, as I mentioned, is text itself is very difficult to understand for computers.
So here are three simple examples where I have highlighted the word Chicago.
So here in this case none of the mentions of Chicago actually mentioned the location Chicago, so it has a different meaning.
So in First 2 cases.
Chicago actually means the typeface, which is the name of the font used in Macintosh, and another three cases is sexually Chicago.
The band and two of those to the two of the other mentions are dimensions of the albums that disbands actually produced, so we can see that the words actually can mean.
The same word can mean a lot of different things, and it's highly.
It's highly ambiguous to understand what the text actually is about.
And Additionally, we also have this kind of variability where you have the word Macintosh and Mac, which actually are two different words, which means the same thing.

So what you actually have to do if you want to understand the text, you have to have a kind of a knowledge base and you have to have a technology which somehow Maps the text using the whole document or whole context of the document into account to actually know what is the correct meaning of individual words.
And that's a semantic annotation.
And it's a whole area of research called entity linking that does this.
And we have a system which is able to do this automatically for 100 languages.
Another task, which also requires machine learning is for example content that we collect is in different languages.
So how do we know if an article in one language is similar to the article in another language or if it's about the same thing?
Of course, if you have small amount of data you can just do the Google translator, whatever on on the documents and translate into the same language.
But this becomes very expensive, so that's why in this case, for example we use statistical approach where we apply Canonical correlation analysis.
Which somehow simplifies things.
So it's um, it Maps original data into some artificial space, and in this space you can then save to.
Documents are similar 0.5 or 0.7 or whatever.
Another task, which is also very critical in our case, is grouping of the articles.
So assuming that you have many articles in one particular language, some of these articles talk about the same event.
So how do we find them?
How do you group them together?
And here again, it's an approach which is widely used in machine learning, which is online clustering algorithm.
In this case, which is able to find groups of articles that talk about the same event and puts them together.
Even when you have this kind of clusters in one language, you might have another group of clusters in another language.

You have to decide now if, for example, if this group of articles in English is talking about the same event as a group of articles in Spanish and here again we can, we can apply machine learning and build models to do this automatically.
Once we have one or more groups of articles, we can then form an event and we can from those articles, extract all the event information that we saw before in that template.
And I switched.
To the demo.
So that you can see actually how the system works on life.
So the system is also publicly available so you can test it yourself so the the URL is event registry.org.
On the on the landing page we show the the What's currently coming into the system.
So the events which are currently being updated based on the latest news which comes in.
Then we have some statistics.

Currently we have about 200 million news articles in the system from which we were able to identify 6 million events and here are some of the things which are currently trending in the news and here are some top recent events from the last two days.
What I want to show now is a little bit of this search, so assuming that we don't have events, assuming that we just have articles like, you usually would if you go to, let's say, Google News.
And let's say that you're interested in hurricanes.
Let's say that you you doing some research on weather changes or whatever.
What you would get if you search on Google News, you simply get a long list of news articles, right?
So you get in our case you get half a million news articles related to hurricanes and here you don't practically get any.
Any summary any.
Advanced view on any like this view.
From the distance of what's actually hidden in this data.
So these are just raw articles.
On the other hand, if you just say OK, let's switch to the events what you can get is much more.
Detailed information, so let me zoom in a little bit.
So what you get is individual hurricanes, right?
So you have on top you have the latest one so we have Hurricane Maria.
Then you have the tropical storm Jose Max which is which was headed to Mexico.
Then you have your mind so on and so on.
So you have all this data automatically organized into something which is meaningful.
So instead of having like lists and lists of individual articles, you simply have kind of a summary of different events.
In this case related to hurricane.
But this is not also OK.
In this case we still have 18,000 events, but we can also somehow aggregate aggregate in visualize this kind of this list of events.
So one of the things you can do is simply we can say OK, what are these events about Hurricane also about?
And you get the kind of a summary.
So on the left side you have the entities, so people, locations, organizations which are most frequently mentioned in the in the events about hurricanes.
So you see United States, Florida taxes, Haiti, Mexico and so on and on the other hand you have known entities.
So things which are not people, locations, and organizations.
So we have Tropical Cyclone, storm, rain, wind, flood and so on.
What's even more interesting is you can say OK, show me the timeline.
So is there any pattern you know when these events actually happen?
And of course there is right.
So you see, this is the latest one.
So here is the summer of this year, so we have a huge spike.
And then if you go back you see another spike.
And this is basically like one year ago and then you have another spike not so big again, which is another year ago.
So you can easily see that this is like a periodic thing which is happening.
Another thing that you can easily also view is the locations of the events.
So as we said, so we also extract the locations where the events actually happened and you can see them visualized on a map.
So let's say that we.

If so, instead of showing individual dots because there are like many thousands of dots, we just show these groups and these groups basically tell you the number of events that happen in that particular region, so we can see that there is a majority of actually hurricanes or events about hurricanes happening in this region here, which is what we would expect, of course, but we also have.
Other areas like we have also related to Hong Kong and China and also.
A Philippines here.

So this is an you can also Additionally think, maybe you can also select the sub subset of time window and you can say OK in this time window there were these hurricanes and then you can easily just move on and you can see how intensity of the events happened for that particular time window.
Maybe another visualization that summarizes this kind of data is categorization, so all these events are also categorized into categories such as business, politics, sports, and so on and so on.
So we have about 5000 categories like this.
And this is a kind of a visualization of the of all these categories.
So on the most inner level, we have the broad category like science.
And here we have business, SoC, News and so on.
And on the sub level we have a sub category inside science in this case.
So we have earth Sciences and we have atmospheric Sciences.
So we have 14% of events about cyclones.
About hurricanes are actually specifically about atmospheric Sciences, but we also have subcategory here.
For example, inside business energy we have renewable energy and here we have a sub category called oil and gas.
So by clicking on the category you can easily see.
Now the Hurricanes and the impact they have on business.
In this case oil and gas.
So you can see for example here we have an event which describes how Hurricane Harvey actually.
Impacts the crude oil price.
So this would be maybe a enough I think.
Also, we're running a bit out of time regarding the individual visualizations that you can do.
Maybe just a single thing.
So for each event you can also not only view the template that you see here, but you can open the event and you can see the individual news reports about this event.
So here I clicked for example Maria and we have all the articles that describe that we see that describe Maria and you can also switch, let's say from German, from English to German coverage.
So you can see all the different languages and how they report about the same event.

On top of that, you can also let's say, visualize who are the new sources that report about this, how they are geographically distributed, and Additionally you can also find let's say similar events, which would be like.
So this is an event which is about hurricane and a particular set of locations.
But you can also find related events in the past which are similar in this kind of fingerprint, and you can visualize them like this.
Or you can put him on a timeline and you can then scroll scroll between them.
So I'm finished, yeah, so I think this would be it so.
No.
